instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message: Customer sent in a 820 3115 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>,  said he received  it from a friend hes not sure what they might have done, he used it for about 8 months and then it stopped working. i opened it up,  some liquid damage, but more interesting was metallic looking flakes all over and what looks like they heated the thing up at one point. the screen was even making lines down it.  it turns on and boots to the apple logo it then shows the mouse cursor and then flashes screens and back to the apple logo and just keeps repeating.  i was thinking at first the liquid and metallic stuff might had been making a short causing it to cycle boot but i ran it through the uc and that took away the black lines but its still cycle booting.  i put in a test os x drive to confirm its not the drive.  any specific components or areas i should take note of here? tried removing everything unnecessary but no change.  i cant seem to find asd 3s150 anywhere so haven't been able to run any asd tests unfortunately.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message: Boot off USB drive to eliminate bad HDD cable and check RAM one slot at a time.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message: Yes booted off usb drive same issue. checked each ram slot nothing changed.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message: Awesome thanks Duke really appreciate it!  will run that fist thing here and post back with update

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message: It passed efi test. do they make ads os for 3s150?  any ideas to test or look around for?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message:
The OS version will probably cycle boot too. You said it had liquid damage, at this point you need to inspect for corroded resistors or traces.
Does it shut off completely and chime again and then boot?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message: The exact problem is, i turn it on apple logo appears, then it goes to start the os screen and the mouse cursor shows up then it hits reload again the mouse goes away and then comes back ( it does not boot back to the apple logo but instead stays at the final boot up with the spinning load circle.  But right now i was just testing to tell you exactly what it does and its been lagging for a few secs at the startup but then opens into os normally i tried this 3 times now and it seems to be working. not sure why it works and then doesn't. it still seems to be doing it though i tried 5 times and now its doing the same thing over and over load spin the mouse shows up goes away and the load spins again it keeps doing this until i restart. unlike before when it was lagging but would end up fully loading.  The owner also said that sometimes if he put pressure on the macbook it would fully boot for him also.    I will look for traces of damaged areas. there was never any corrosion.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message: This was probably an  impact damage. Have you tried just using 1 RAM slot, could have 1 bad one. Besides that I think this will be a scrapper.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message:
hmm, the case itself does not seem to appear dropped.  i have tried each ram slot. i did find some nasty stuff under a lot of parts tried pulling and  cleaning the obvious ones but that didnt help. im going to uc it again and see if there isnt something under some chips.  

as always appreciate the help duke.  i will post back if i do ever get it running normal. 
Thanks Again!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message: surprisingly it loads into safe mode everytime haha

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message: Boot in verbose mode and see where is crashes.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message: ever since i booted it in safe mode and tried booting normal it worked and hasn't hung up on the load screen again yet after 10 tries. it still is working but dont want to think its fixed out of the air lol. i did boot in verbose mode it wont crash as it end up fully booting into osx not sure if that just part of the luck im having right now. took some photos of the verbose. let me know if you can read that.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message:
also im getting blocks on the screen from the T4001, it only happens if the computer gets tapped or bumped and if i press on the t4001 it fixes it for a short time. (idk what the proper name is for it).  How do i fix or replace this?

 i have been able to boot into osx fully with no troubles so far not sure what the prob could be or was, still got me pretty tripped out haha

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message: Blocks are an indication of an issue with the RAM. You already tested one slot at a time so this board is trash now. Probably cracked traces under RAM slots or CPU, the end.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> cycle booting
threads.message:
okay yeah thats right i press on the ram slot only one was installed. and it messed up blocks on the screen i put the stick in the other slot and it wont make blocks if i press on the ram area or if i bang it around etc seems good on the other ram slot. and the problem with loading into osx seems to be gone also. im not sure if its fully trash if they just use one ram slot.  ( the top ram slot im using now had broken tabs so its possible the tab was making it not work last time i tested it, i Placed a piece to put pressure on the side clamp and its holding the ram nicely)

Thanks again for all the help and info! this one seems to be solved and is working but with out one ram slot.
